conclusion: To determine when objects A and B meet, analyze the velocity-time graphs and find where their positions become equal.
Both objects start at the same position.
Object A's velocity-time graph consists of straight line segments: from 0 to t₂, velocity increases linearly from 0 to v₀; from t₂ to t₄, velocity decreases linearly from v₀ to 0.
Object B's velocity-time graph consists of curved segments: from 0 to t₃, velocity decreases from v₀ toward 0 (exponential decay); from t₃ to t₄, velocity increases from near 0 back to v₀.
Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time (area under the velocity-time curve).
The position of each object at any time t is equal to the area under its velocity-time curve from 0 to t.
The second image shows red horizontal lines representing equal time intervals, which can be used for area calculations via rectangular approximations.
For the objects to meet, they must have traveled the same distance from their starting point, meaning the areas under their respective velocity-time curves must be equal at that moment.
Initially, object B has greater velocity than object A.
Object B's position increases more rapidly at first due to its greater velocity.
At some point, object A's velocity exceeds object B's.
When object A's velocity exceeds object B's, object A starts catching up to object B.
The objects' positions become equal when the areas under their velocity-time curves become equal.
The red shading in the second image shows the areas under both curves becoming equal at time t₃.

At time t₃, object A has covered an area equal to the triangle from 0 to t₂ plus part of the triangle from t₂ to t₃, while object B has covered an area equal to the region under its decay curve from 0 to t₃.
The areas under the curves being equal at t₃ means the objects have traveled the same distance and therefore meet at time t₃.
The two objects meet at time t₃.
